title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify the procedures for issuing warrants by a court of competent jurisdiction in various subsections. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify procedures for issuing warrants by a court of competent jurisdiction, including district courts and courts of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated or acting on a request for foreign assistance. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify procedures for issuing warrants by a court of competent jurisdiction, including district courts and courts of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated or acting on a request for foreign assistance. The amendments detail the specific criteria for courts authorized to issue search warrants in criminal investigations. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify procedures for issuing warrants by a court of competent jurisdiction, including district courts and courts of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated or acting on a request for foreign assistance. The amendments detail the specific criteria for courts authorized to issue search warrants in criminal investigations, including the execution of foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions. This includes the issuance of search warrants as provided under rule 41 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. The amended Title 18 of the United States Code outlines procedures for issuing warrants by courts of competent jurisdiction, including district courts and courts of appeals. This includes the issuance of search warrants, warrants for electronic communications, pen register orders, and orders for testimony or document production in response to foreign requests for assistance. Additionally, Federal judges may appoint individuals to oversee the taking of testimony or statements and the production of documents in such cases. The amended Title 18 of the United States Code allows for the appointment of individuals to oversee the taking of testimony, statements, and production of documents in response to foreign requests for assistance. Appointed persons have the authority to issue orders for appearance, administer oaths, and receive documents. Requests for execution of foreign authority requests can be filed in the district where the person resides or where the documents are located. The amended Title 18 of the United States Code allows for the appointment of individuals to oversee the taking of testimony, statements, and production of documents in response to foreign requests for assistance. Requests for search warrants from foreign authorities must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. Federal judges can issue search warrants only for foreign offenses punishable by imprisonment for more than one year under Federal or State law. Orders or warrants issued under this section can be served or executed anywhere in the United States. An order or warrant issued under this section can be served anywhere in the United States. Foreign authorities or interested persons can seek assistance in criminal investigations through section 1782 of title 28, US Code. Definitions for "Federal judge" and "foreign authority" are provided in this section. The curr_chunk adds a provision for seeking assistance in criminal matters under an agreement or treaty with the United States. The curr_chunk adds a provision for foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions.
